title: How to Clean Your Plae Shoes

steps.headline: Evaluate the dirt.
steps.description: Before you pop your shoes in the washing machine or use a harsh cleaning solution, estimate the stain or dirt. Some smudges can be easily removed with a damp cloth or suede cleaning brush. If your shoes have a bad odour, you need to clean only the insole rather than the entire shoe.

steps.headline: Brush off the mud.
steps.description: If your shoes have mud stains, wait for it to dry. Spread a newspaper on a flat surface or just take the shoes outside to brush off the dried mud with a toothbrush or a shoe cleaning brush. You can follow it up by wiping the shoes clean with a damp cloth.

steps.headline: Clean leather with a dirt-removing solution.
steps.description: Scuffs marks on Plae canvas or leather footwear can be cleaned with dirt removing solutions such as  Mr. Clean Magic Erasers and acetone nail polish remover. Apply the solution on the dirt and let it sit for a while. Keep rubbing the stain with a cloth till it disappears completely. You can also make such a solution at home. Add 1 teaspoon of Borax and 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) of baking soda to half a cup of hot water. Stir the mixture and place a melamine sponge to soak up the solution. Squeeze out the excess and start cleaning. This method is also effective to remove stains made by permanent markers and biodegradable substances such as grass, blood etc.

steps.headline: Clean the insole with detergent.
steps.description: If the insoles are stained or have an unpleasant odour, remove them from the shoes for cleaning. Air the shoes with the tongue lifted up in a shaded, dry spot outside or place them under a fan. Soak the insoles in warm water with a few drops of detergent. Use a shoe brush to scrub them clean and then rinse. Clip them onto a clothesline to dry. Make sure the insoles are dry before you put them in. Reduce the odour by placing strips of dryer sheets in each shoe overnight. Wear clean socks with your footwear to avoid staining the insole.

steps.headline: Hand-wash only the stained area with laundry soap and baking soda.
steps.description: If only a portion of your shoe is stained, you can do instant spot cleaning only for that part. Wet the dirty area with a solution of water, laundry soap and baking soda for 15-20 minutes. Then, use a toothbrush to scrub the dirt. After that, rinse the portion thoroughly and leave it to dry.

steps.headline: Soak the footwear in lukewarm detergent water before wash. Soaking the dirty shoes prior to machine-washing makes the stains easier to come off.
steps.description: Mix 1 teaspoon of detergent or fabric softener in a bucket of lukewarm water. Then, put the shoes in the bucket for 15-20 minutes. Avoid adding too much detergent as it will be difficult to wash off. Add 1 teaspoon of cleaner to half a bucket of water for one pair of shoes. You can soak the separated insole, laces and shoes in the same bucket.

steps.headline: Choose the gentle cycle setting.
steps.description: Non-leather shoe styles can be easily cleaned in a washing machine. Opt for a cold, gentle cycle. If the water temperature is a separate setting on your machine, choose cold.

steps.headline: Cushion your shoes for the wash cycle.
steps.description: Washing shoes on their own in the machine is a noisy affair and the friction can damage them. Pad them up by putting heavy linen such as towels in the same wash. You can even put the shoes inside a pillowcase or a shoe bag before popping them in for a wash. Knot the laces together and place them in the pillowcase before putting it in the washer. This will prevent the laces from getting stuck in the drainage holes and make it easier to find the correct pair. Do not put your expensive or light-coloured linen for a wash along with grimy shoes.

steps.headline: Go for extra rinse mode.
steps.description: Residual detergent after the wash tends to discolour or stiffen the footwear. So, opt for an extra rinse to remove any soap residue. If your machine does not have an extra rinse mode, place the shoes under running water to wash off the leftover detergent.

steps.headline: Do not place the shoes in the dryer.
steps.description: Not all shoes can be put in the dryer, especially not your Plae shoes. Tumble drying shoes may lead them to lose their shape or damage the rubber soles.

steps.headline: Air dry in a shaded area if you are not pressed for time.
steps.description: Air-drying recently-washed shoes outdoors may be a slower process depending on the weather of your area. So, plan the footwear washing on sunny days. Hang out the laces, insole on a clothesline and place the uppers upside down against a wall in a shady patch. Avoid direct sunlight or extremely cold weather as it may damage your shoes.

steps.headline: Stuff the shoes with newspaper and blow-dry for a quicker fix.
steps.description: If air-drying is not a feasible option, you can also dry your shoes indoors quickly. Take out the insoles from the shoes and hang them to dry. Then, place balled up newspapers inside the shoes to absorb the excess water and blow-dry them using a hairdryer on the medium or cool heat setting. Make sure to keep replacing the newspaper stuffing once it gets damp. This method is ideal to avoid shrinkage and keeps the shape of your footwear intact. If you don’t have a hairdryer, place the wet shoes stuffed with newspapers under the fan or at a distance from the heater.

text: Cleaning Small Stains Evaluate the dirt. Before you pop your shoes in the washing machine or use a harsh cleaning solution, estimate the stain or dirt. Some smudges can be easily removed with a damp cloth or suede cleaning brush. If your shoes have a bad odour, you need to clean only the insole rather than the entire shoe. Brush off the mud. If your shoes have mud stains, wait for it to dry. Spread a newspaper on a flat surface or just take the shoes outside to brush off the dried mud with a toothbrush or a shoe cleaning brush. You can follow it up by wiping the shoes clean with a damp cloth. Clean leather with a dirt-removing solution. Scuffs marks on Plae canvas or leather footwear can be cleaned with dirt removing solutions such as  Mr. Clean Magic Erasers and acetone nail polish remover. Apply the solution on the dirt and let it sit for a while. Keep rubbing the stain with a cloth till it disappears completely. You can also make such a solution at home. Squeeze out the excess and start cleaning. Machine-Washing The Shoes Soak the footwear in lukewarm detergent water before wash. Soaking the dirty shoes prior to machine-washing makes the stains easier to come off. Mix 1 teaspoon of detergent or fabric softener in a bucket of lukewarm water. Then, put the shoes in the bucket for 15-20 minutes. Avoid adding too much detergent as it will be difficult to wash off. Add 1 teaspoon of cleaner to half a bucket of water for one pair of shoes. You can soak the separated insole, laces and shoes in the same bucket. Choose the gentle cycle setting. Non-leather shoe styles can be easily cleaned in a washing machine. Opt for a cold, gentle cycle. If the water temperature is a separate setting on your machine, choose cold. Cushion your shoes for the wash cycle. Washing shoes on their own in the machine is a noisy affair and the friction can damage them. Pad them up by putting heavy linen such as towels in the same wash. You can even put the shoes inside a pillowcase or a shoe bag before popping them in for a wash. Knot the laces together and place them in the pillowcase before putting it in the washer. This will prevent the laces from getting stuck in the drainage holes and make it easier to find the correct pair. Do not put your expensive or light-coloured linen for a wash along with grimy shoes. Go for extra rinse mode. Residual detergent after the wash tends to discolour or stiffen the footwear. So, opt for an extra rinse to remove any soap residue. If your machine does not have an extra rinse mode, place the shoes under running water to wash off the leftover detergent. Drying The Footwear Do not place the shoes in the dryer. Not all shoes can be put in the dryer, especially not your Plae shoes. Tumble drying shoes may lead them to lose their shape or damage the rubber soles. Air dry in a shaded area if you are not pressed for time. Air-drying recently-washed shoes outdoors may be a slower process depending on the weather of your area. So, plan the footwear washing on sunny days. Hang out the laces, insole on a clothesline and place the uppers upside down against a wall in a shady patch. Avoid direct sunlight or extremely cold weather as it may damage your shoes. Stuff the shoes with newspaper and blow-dry for a quicker fix. If air-drying is not a feasible option, you can also dry your shoes indoors quickly. Take out the insoles from the shoes and hang them to dry. Then, place balled up newspapers inside the shoes to absorb the excess water and blow-dry them using a hairdryer on the medium or cool heat setting. Make sure to keep replacing the newspaper stuffing once it gets damp. This method is ideal to avoid shrinkage and keeps the shape of your footwear intact. If you don’t have a hairdryer, place the wet shoes stuffed with newspapers under the fan or at a distance from the heater.
tyn_model: damp cloth or suede cleaning brush
